sections.appendix a hierarchical polynomial parti:
The idea of a hierarchical polynomial partition is very similar to the
earlier constructions of hierarchical cuttings, proposed by Chazelle  and
by Matoušek  already in the 1990s. Still, it has hardly been used
in the context of polynomial partitionings, mostly because almost all the applications
of this technique to date have been combinatorial, so the issue of efficient algorithmic
construction of the partitioning polynomial seldom arises. One notable early exception
is the work of Agarwal et al. [ref]2, mentioned above, which uses a data structure similar
to the one developed here, albeit in a different context.
More recent algorithms are by Aronov et al.  and by Agarwal et al. ,
which construct polynomial partitions for a set of varieties. We begin by presenting the hierarchical approach for planar point sets. Let P𝑃P be
a set of n𝑛n points in the plane, and let 1≤r≤n1𝑟𝑛1\leq r\leq n be an integer parameter.
Our goal is to efficiently obtain a hierarchical polynomial partitioning of P𝑃P into
O​(n/r)𝑂𝑛𝑟O(n/r) subsets, each of size at most r𝑟r, that has properties similar to the single
partitioning of Guth and Katz —see below. The following easy (but useful) property is related to, but is much simpler than
Proposition 2.1. Let γ⊂ℝ2𝛾superscriptℝ2\gamma\subset\mathbb{R}^{2} be an algebraic curve of degree δ𝛿\delta,
containing a finite set Q𝑄Q. Then there is a subset X⊂γ∖Q𝑋𝛾𝑄X\subset\gamma\setminus Q
of O​(δ2)𝑂superscript𝛿2O(\delta^{2}) points, such that γ∖X𝛾𝑋\gamma\setminus X consists of O​(δ2)𝑂superscript𝛿2O(\delta^{2})
arcs, each containing at most |Q|/δ2𝑄superscript𝛿2\lvert Q\rvert/\delta^{2} points of Q𝑄Q.
Moreover, each point p∈X𝑝𝑋p\in X has an open neighborhood on γ𝛾\gamma (disjoint from Q𝑄Q) such that any
point of that neighborhood could replace p𝑝p without affecting the partitioning property.
The partition can be constructed in O​(|Q|)𝑂𝑄O(\lvert Q\rvert) time, where the constant of proportionality
depends on δ𝛿\delta. Proposition 2.1 yields a partitioning with a
single polynomial f𝑓f of degree O​(n/r)𝑂𝑛𝑟O(\sqrt{n/r}). However, when r𝑟r is relatively small
(so the degree of f𝑓f is large), the computation of the partition might be costly.
Concretely, the best algorithm for constructing (an approximation of)
such a polynomial is the algorithm by Agarwal et al. [ref]2,
which runs in randomized expected time O​(n2/r+n3/r3)𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑟superscript𝑛3superscript𝑟3O(n^{2}/r+n^{3}/r^{3}). To circumvent this issue, we resort to a hierarchical approach,
where we recursively construct polynomial partitioning of appropriately chosen
constant degree. That is, let D≥1𝐷1D\geq 1 be a sufficiently large constant.151515As we will shortly describe, D𝐷D depends on the prescribed parameter ε𝜀\varepsilon.
We apply Proposition 2.1 with degree O​(D)𝑂𝐷O(D) and Proposition A.1 with δ=D𝛿𝐷\delta=D,
and obtain a partition of P𝑃P into at most c​D2𝑐superscript𝐷2cD^{2} one- and two-dimensional cells,
for a suitable absolute constant c>0𝑐0c>0, so that each cell contains at most n/D2𝑛superscript𝐷2n/D^{2} points of P𝑃P.
We then recurse with each two-dimensional (resp., one-dimensional) cell τ𝜏\tau by applying
Propositions 2.1 and A.1
(resp., only Proposition A.1)
to P∩τ𝑃𝜏P\cap\tau. The procedure for the one-dimensional case is trivial to perform. However, the second-level cells τ′superscript𝜏′\tau^{\prime} produced at τ𝜏\tau do not have
to be contained in τ𝜏\tau, so the decomposition of the plane that all the second-level cells
produce, over all τ𝜏\tau, is not necessarily a partition of the plane.
We handle this as follows: The subset associated with a child cell τ′superscript𝜏′\tau^{\prime} of the partition
is formed by intersecting τ′superscript𝜏′\tau^{\prime} with the set associated with its parent cell τ𝜏\tau;
only the points of P𝑃P in that intersection are passed to the subproblem at τ′superscript𝜏′\tau^{\prime}.
If this set is empty, we do not create a recursive subproblem at τ′superscript𝜏′\tau^{\prime}. With this modification,
the subsets of P𝑃P associated with the current level of recursion form a partition of P𝑃P. We obtain, in the second recursive stage, a collection of at most c2​D4superscript𝑐2superscript𝐷4c^{2}D^{4} cells,
each of which is associated with a subset of at most n/D4𝑛superscript𝐷4n/D^{4} points of P𝑃P which
the cell contains (in addition to other points that the cell might also contain
but which are not associated with it). We continue in this manner recursively, so that at the
j𝑗jth level of recursion we get at most cj​D2​jsuperscript𝑐𝑗superscript𝐷2𝑗c^{j}D^{2j} cells, each associated with a subset
of at most n/D2​j𝑛superscript𝐷2𝑗n/D^{2j} points of P𝑃P which it contains.
(The situation shares common features with the simplicial partitioning scheme
of Matoušek , which is based on standard cuttings.)
The recursion terminates when the number of points in a cell is at most r𝑟r.
This leads to a simple recurrence on the number of cells, which solves to
the bound O​((n/r)1+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛𝑟1𝜀O((n/r)^{1+\varepsilon}), for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 (ε𝜀\varepsilon depends on D𝐷D,
or rather D𝐷D depends on ε𝜀\varepsilon; to achieve a bound with a smaller ε𝜀\varepsilon we need to increase D𝐷D,
and pay for the improved bound with a larger constant of proportionality).
In particular, this is an upper bound on the number of cells obtained at the last level.
We refer to them as the bottom-level cells. So far, this hierarchical construction makes little sense, as there are many other
(more trivial) ways to partition P𝑃P in this manner. It is the next observation that
makes the hierarchical partition useful, as it shows that the partitioning almost possesses
(with an ε𝜀\varepsilon-loss in the exponents)
the same properties as does a standard polynomial partition. Specifically, let
γ𝛾\gamma be an algebraic curve of constant degree b𝑏b, and suppose that D𝐷D is chosen
to be sufficiently larger than b𝑏b (see below).
We bound the number of cells in the decomposition of P𝑃P that γ𝛾\gamma
reaches, where we say, as above, that γ𝛾\gamma reaches a cell τ𝜏\tau if γ𝛾\gamma intersects
τ𝜏\tau and all its ancestral cells. Bounding the number of these cells proceeds as follows. At the first level of recursion, γ𝛾\gamma meets at most b​D+1𝑏𝐷1bD+1 cells,
which easily follows from Bézout’s theorem. Clearly, γ𝛾\gamma reaches all these cells.
Let Xγ​(n)subscript𝑋𝛾𝑛X_{\gamma}(n) be an upper bound on the maximum number of cells
in a partition of n𝑛n points that γ𝛾\gamma reaches.161616This recurrence counts the number of reached cells at all levels of the hierarchy.
If we are only interested in the number of bottom-level cells that γ𝛾\gamma reaches,
the nonrecursive term b​D+1𝑏𝐷1bD+1 should be removed.
We then obtain the recurrence for n>r𝑛𝑟n>r. For n≤r𝑛𝑟n\leq r, Xγ​(n)=1subscript𝑋𝛾𝑛1X_{\gamma}(n)=1, as no further partitioning is done in this case.
Using induction on n𝑛n, it is easy to verify that the solution is
Xγ​(n)=O​((n/r)1/2+ε)subscript𝑋𝛾𝑛𝑂superscript𝑛𝑟12𝜀X_{\gamma}(n)=O((n/r)^{1/2+\varepsilon}), for any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, as long as we
choose D𝐷D sufficiently larger than b1/(2​ε)superscript𝑏12𝜀b^{1/(2\varepsilon)}.
Thus, as promised, this hierarchical partition has similar properties to polynomial partitioning
with a single polynomial of degree O​(n/r)𝑂𝑛𝑟O(\sqrt{n/r}) (up to the extra ε𝜀\varepsilon in the exponent): Let P𝑃P be a set of n𝑛n points in the plane, let 1≤r≤n1𝑟𝑛1\leq r\leq n be an integer parameter,
and ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 be an arbitrarily small number. Then the following hold: 
(i) There is a hierarchical polynomial partition for P𝑃P with O​((n/r)1+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛𝑟1𝜀O((n/r)^{1+\varepsilon}) bottom-level cells,
each of which is associated with at most r𝑟r points of P𝑃P which it contains.
The overall number of cells is also O​((n/r)1+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛𝑟1𝜀O((n/r)^{1+\varepsilon}). 
(ii) Any algebraic curve γ𝛾\gamma of constant degree reaches (in the meaning
defined above) at most O​((n/r)1/2+ε)𝑂superscript𝑛𝑟12𝜀O((n/r)^{1/2+\varepsilon}) cells at all levels of this partition. 
The constants in the bounds depend on ε𝜀\varepsilon and on the degree of γ𝛾\gamma. The analysis of algorithms for constructing this partition, as well as its
extensions to higher dimensions, presented next, will be given later in this section.
